name: Inside the Wasp Nest: Understanding Insect Societies
description: Many species of insects—such as ants, bees, wasps, and termites—organise themselves into societies, resembling and in some ways surpassing human societies. Can we understand these insect societies? Dive into ant-hills, wasp nests, and beehives by joining us for this talk by ecologist Raghavendra Gadagkar, who will share his research around the Indian paper wasp Ropalidia marginata. Learn about the observational and experimental methods used to study insects, discover contemporary research around these bugs, and judge how much we know of this often neglected society!

name: Tracing Materials: From Resource to Waste to Art
description:
What does ‘material’ or ‘medium’ mean to an artist? Do materials themselves provide rich narratives and social histories? Visual artist Arunkumar H G certainly thinks so! In this workshop he delves into the origins and historical contexts of materials, while they transform from resources to waste.

For this workshop, you are encouraged to bring your own accumulation of waste, to examine how we perceive and interpret waste. You will then work with Arunkumar H G to transform these materials into art objects, highlighting the qualities and significance of the seemingly mundane.

name: Building Resilient Climate Futures: Exploring AI in Climate Action
description:
Can AI and other technological tools affect the future of climate action in Asia? And how can you assess these nuanced climate futures?

Join researchers Dona Mathew and Sasha John in a workshop that delves into the intersection of AI and climate action, while highlighting the Digital Futures Lab's research. Discover how to spot trends and signals that hint at future climate scenarios through hands-on activities. Imagine and design the climate futures you want to see, guided by foresight methodologies and creative thinking exercises.
